3jkv.name: Why do you want to become an entrepreneur?
3jkv.value:
I have decided to become an entrepreneur as a job creator, problem solver and meet the need of society and create opportunities for others to thrive.

I want to build businesses that last or ventures that will create more jobs and drive innovations in the societies

mFMG.name: Why now, and what has stopped you starting a business already?
mFMG.value:
I believe the timing is right now because i have gained experience on how businesses are run, insight on how decisions are made and what kind of structures need to be put in place for businesses to grow. More reason now is that technology has reduced the barrier to entry 

What stoped me beforer was i was gathering knowledge and experience,

9po8.name: What are your strongest skills / specific things you want to be doing in the early stages of your new business?
9po8.value:
My strongest skills are strategy, communication and execution.

What i will be doing at the early stage of the business is to build the system, build a team, customer acquisition and development and brand positioning

5HJE.name: What are your main skill gaps where you'll need help?
5HJE.value: Investment planning and financial management, leadership development and hiring, advanced supply chain management and operational efficiency and technological integration

qG1G.name: Which industry do you want to build a business in, and why?
qG1G.value:
Manufacturing and Agriculture

The main reason is that both the agriculture and manufacturing intersect, one produce raw materials while the other add value to the raw materials to make finished goods, creating jobs, reducing imports, and driving exports. I see a real opportunity to process what we grow locally into finished or semi-finished products that meet domestic and international demand.

hN3D.name: Do you have any notable connections, insights, expertise or advantages in this industry? Tell us more about that.
hN3D.value:
As Executive Director of Spaceway Limited, I’ve managed operations in the manufacturing sector, particularly in adhesive tape production — overseeing sourcing, production efficiency, and market distribution. This experience has helped me understand machinery setup, supply chain challenges, and quality control in a local manufacturing context.

In addition, through Captain Farm and Consultancy, I’ve developed a strong network in agriculture, especially among farmers, agro-dealers, and input suppliers in Southwest Nigeria. This has given me deep insights into local production systems, market gaps, and opportunities for agro-processing.

rJ3u.name: What trends or shifts in your industry are you most excited about? Why?
rJ3u.value:
I’m most excited about the growing shift toward local value addition and agro-processing. More entrepreneurs are realizing that instead of exporting raw materials, we can process them locally into higher-value products — creating jobs, saving foreign exchange, and strengthening local industries.

I’m also inspired by the rise of agritech and smart manufacturing — from precision farming and digital marketplaces to automation and data-driven production. These innovations are making both sectors more efficient, traceable, and scalable.

tZ42.name: What is the specific problem in your industry that you want to solve?
tZ42.value:
The main problem I want to solve is the disconnect between agricultural production and manufacturing capacity.

Nigeria produces abundant raw materials — crops, livestock, and natural resources — but most are sold in unprocessed form, leading to low farmer income, high post-harvest losses, and overdependence on imported finished goods.

At the same time, many small manufacturers struggle with inconsistent supply, poor-quality inputs, and lack of affordable local processing solutions.

7wHz.name: Who is experiencing this problem?
7wHz.value: This problem is being experienced by both farmers and small manufacturers across Nigeria and other developing economies

hKVV.name: How are people getting around this problem at the moment?
hKVV.value:
Farmers often sell their produce to middlemen at low prices just to avoid spoilage, instead of processing or storing it.

Manufacturers rely heavily on imported raw materials because local inputs are inconsistent in quality and supply

qFLN.name: Will solving this problem save people time or money (or both)? How much time or money?
qFLN.value: Solving this problem will save both time and money across the entire value chain.  For farmers, access to local processing and manufacturing outlets will reduce post-harvest losses by up to 30–40%, while increasing income since they can sell at better prices.  For manufacturers, reliable local inputs will cut import costs by 20–35% and shorten production lead times by weeks, since they won’t have to depend on foreign shipments or currency fluctuations

mymB.name: Approximately how many people are affected by this problem?
mymB.value:
This problem affects millions of people across Nigeria — directly and indirectly.

Nigeria has over 38 million smallholder farmers, according to the Federal Ministry of Agriculture, and the vast majority lack access to reliable processing or storage facilities. Even if we focus on just 10% of them, that’s nearly 4 million farmers losing value every harvest.

On the other side, there are an estimated 80,000+ small and medium manufacturers, many of whom rely on imported raw materials because local inputs aren’t processed to the required standard.

When you include transporters, distributors, and consumers affected by higher costs and delays, the total market impact easily reaches tens of millions of Nigerians — representing a multi-billion-naira opportunity to strengthen local production chains.

9CiT.name: Do you already an idea in mind for what could solve this problem?

tcTa.name: Walk us through this idea:What your solution actuallydoesWhy it’s a smart way to solve the problemHow it compares to what people use nowWhat makes your approach different or better

dNQ5.name: How do you think you'll get your first 1 - 10 customers?

chXn.name: How much do you think people will pay for this? And why do you think that number?

wFSJ.name: Who is your main competition, and what are they getting wrong?
wFSJ.value:
My main competition comes from importers of finished and semi-processed goods, as well as large processing companies that dominate certain value chains.

Importers are meeting demand but not solving the local production gap — they keep Nigeria dependent on foreign supply, draining foreign exchange and limiting local job creation. Their model focuses on trading, not transformation.

8iZG.name: How many hours / days a week are you able to commit to working on your business now while still part time?

mRvX.name: What does success look like for you?
value: A profitable lifestyle business with a good salary and regular dividends
A business I can pass on to future generations

9iJC.name: If things go well, would you be comfortable raising external capital for your business?

v8MM.name: Are there people in your network you could pitch to for some early startup funding?
v8MM.value: Yes, but they probably wouldn’t invest in my business

gYjH.name: Do you consider yourself to be someone that is “hands-on” or you prefer to hire people to do the work?
gYjH.value: Yes, Hands-on but as the business expand hiring is very important

nCYJ.name: Imagine one year from now, the business is showing signs of success and you’ve quit your job to go full time on this. What does your typical day-to-day look like?
nCYJ.value: working full time on the business and training a successors

mJME.name: As a founder coming from the corporate world, it’s typical to take a salary cut in the early stages of building your business - or even working for a period without pay - so more money can be used on growing the business, which in turn grows your long-term wealth.
mJME.value: Yes, I understand and am prepared to take a reduced salary in the short term.

3BFW.name: What is the minimum annual salary you would need to support yourself while working full-time on your business?

7rP9.name: Why do you want DQventures to work with you on your new business?
7rP9.value: Because of the potential of DQventures to assist in making the dream a reality

vGqM.name: Is there anything else you'd like us to know about you and your goals?

umgN.name: Which country are you currently located in?

8fKT.name: How did you hear about DQventures?

v4TV.name: Before we move forward, please confirm you're aware of the DQventures program structure:We charge a $2000 / month fee to work with our team, and 20% equity in the new company if we enter a full partnership.
v4TV.value: I need more information about how that works

7civ.name: Would you like to proceed?
7civ.value: Yes, I’m able to commit $2k to explore my business idea

grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Approximately how many people are affect: This problem affects millions of people across Nigeria — directly and indirectly.  Nigeria has over 38 million smallholder farmers, according to the Federal Ministry of Agriculture, and the vast majority lack access to reliable processing or storage facilities. Even if we focus on just 10% of them, that’s nearly 4 million farmers losing value every harvest.  On the other side, there are an estimated 80,000+ small and medium manufacturers, many of whom rely on imported raw materials because local inputs aren’t processed to the required standard.  When you include transporters, distributors, and consumers affected by higher costs and delays, the total market impact easily reaches tens of millions of Nigerians — representing a multi-billion-naira opportunity to strengthen local production chains.
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Are there people in your network you cou: Yes, but they probably wouldn’t invest in my business
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Are you aware of the $20k / 20% terms?: I need more information about how that works
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.As a founder coming from the corporate w: Yes, I understand and am prepared to take a reduced salary in the short term.
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Do you consider yourself to be someone t: Yes, Hands-on but as the business expand hiring is very important
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Do you have any notable connections, ins: As Executive Director of Spaceway Limited, I’ve managed operations in the manufacturing sector, particularly in adhesive tape production — overseeing sourcing, production efficiency, and market distribution. This experience has helped me understand machinery setup, supply chain challenges, and quality control in a local manufacturing context.  In addition, through Captain Farm and Consultancy, I’ve developed a strong network in agriculture, especially among farmers, agro-dealers, and input suppliers in Southwest Nigeria. This has given me deep insights into local production systems, market gaps, and opportunities for agro-processing.
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.How are people getting around this probl: Farmers often sell their produce to middlemen at low prices just to avoid spoilage, instead of processing or storing it.  Manufacturers rely heavily on imported raw materials because local inputs are inconsistent in quality and supply
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Imagine one year from now, the business: working full time on the business and training a successors
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Offer Personalization: We’ve selected you because your operator’s vantage point across manufacturing and agriculture gives you credible access to the pain points SME processors will pay to fix—supply inconsistency, quality assurance, and post‑harvest loss. Even without a defined product yet, your network and cost discipline create a viable path to an asset‑light, service‑led wedge—supply assurance and quality standardization, coordinating existing processors and logistics—to reduce lead times and variability without owning plant or inventory. Within DQ’s co‑creation model, we’ll work with you to force‑rank one value chain and a single economic buyer, run 15–20 structured discovery conversations to evidence urgency and budgets, and shape an MVP with measurable SLAs and practical pricing units (per tonne/batch/QC certificate). Your willingness to trade salary for runway and your track record running operations signal the pragmatism our milestone cadence depends on, and we’ll align early on weekly time commitment and venture‑scale ambition. This combination of domain access, operator mindset, and a capital‑light path to value is exactly why we’re inviting you to build with DQventures.
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.What are your main skill gaps where you': Investment planning and financial management, leadership development and hiring, advanced supply chain management and operational efficiency and technological integration
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.What are your strongest skills / specifi: My strongest skills are strategy, communication and execution.  What i will be doing at the early stage of the business is to build the system, build a team, customer acquisition and development and brand positioning
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.What does success look like for you?: A profitable lifestyle business with a good salary and regular dividends,A business I can pass on to future generations
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.What is the specific problem in your ind: The main problem I want to solve is the disconnect between agricultural production and manufacturing capacity.  Nigeria produces abundant raw materials — crops, livestock, and natural resources — but most are sold in unprocessed form, leading to low farmer income, high post-harvest losses, and overdependence on imported finished goods.  At the same time, many small manufacturers struggle with inconsistent supply, poor-quality inputs, and lack of affordable local processing solutions.
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.What trends or shifts in your industry a: I’m most excited about the growing shift toward local value addition and agro-processing. More entrepreneurs are realizing that instead of exporting raw materials, we can process them locally into higher-value products — creating jobs, saving foreign exchange, and strengthening local industries.  I’m also inspired by the rise of agritech and smart manufacturing — from precision farming and digital marketplaces to automation and data-driven production. These innovations are making both sectors more efficient, traceable, and scalable.
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Which industry do you want to build a bu: Manufacturing and Agriculture  The main reason is that both the agriculture and manufacturing intersect, one produce raw materials while the other add value to the raw materials to make finished goods, creating jobs, reducing imports, and driving exports. I see a real opportunity to process what we grow locally into finished or semi-finished products that meet domestic and international demand.
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Who is experiencing this problem?: This problem is being experienced by both farmers and small manufacturers across Nigeria and other developing economies
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Who is your main competition, and what a: My main competition comes from importers of finished and semi-processed goods, as well as large processing companies that dominate certain value chains.  Importers are meeting demand but not solving the local production gap — they keep Nigeria dependent on foreign supply, draining foreign exchange and limiting local job creation. Their model focuses on trading, not transformation.
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Why do you want DQventures to work with: Because of the potential of DQventures to assist in making the dream a reality
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Why do you want to become an entrepreneu: I have decided to become an entrepreneur as a job creator, problem solver and meet the need of society and create opportunities for others to thrive.  I want to build businesses that last or ventures that will create more jobs and drive innovations in the societies
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Why now, and what has stopped you starti: I believe the timing is right now because i have gained experience on how businesses are run, insight on how decisions are made and what kind of structures need to be put in place for businesses to grow. More reason now is that technology has reduced the barrier to entry   What stoped me beforer was i was gathering knowledge and experience,
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Will solving this problem save people ti: Solving this problem will save both time and money across the entire value chain.  For farmers, access to local processing and manufacturing outlets will reduce post-harvest losses by up to 30–40%, while increasing income since they can sell at better prices.  For manufacturers, reliable local inputs will cut import costs by 20–35% and shorten production lead times by weeks, since they won’t have to depend on foreign shipments or currency fluctuations
grp_323c561b-8741-4c14-9a6b-e72bc1dbeb9f.Would you like to proceed?: Yes, I’m able to commit $2k to explore my business idea
